messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Scanning
messages.msgSnippet: Mr. Sanders helpfully identified the term moiré, which I confusedly mistook for something Japanese. On my HP scanner, the Descreen option under Advanced
messages.messageBody:
Mr. Sanders helpfully identified the term moiré, which I confusedly mistook for something Japanese.

On my HP scanner, the Descreen option under Advanced settings is there precisely to cancel out undesirable moiré effects, which I find occur in scanned images of some photographs and postcards. Possibly Canon uses a different term. Just type "moiré" in the Search feature in Help, and I'm sure it will identify Canon's equivalent option.
----- Original Message -----
From: Gordon Robson
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, August 06, 2003 1:09 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Scanning


Hi all,

I'm looking for a little free advice on scanning. I am using a
Canoscan9900F, which is a very good scanner. I begin my scans through
Photoshop 7.0 into ScanGear CS. I have been using very high dpis of
1600 and 800 with the weak morei (spelling?) turned on and the sharp
turned off. I am still getting nasty looking morei in my scans of
oshigata for this summer's lecture. Any ideas on what I need to do to
improve my scans?

Gordon



Yahoo! Groups Sponsor

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Scanning
messages.msgSnippet: A quick follow-up to my previous posting- Instead of scanning at a high resolution in order to capture detail of your oshigata/rubbing, perhaps you could try
messages.messageBody:
A quick follow-up to my previous posting-
Instead of scanning at a high resolution in order to capture detail of your oshigata/rubbing,
perhaps you could try scanning lower dpi, and manipulating the brightness and contrast adjustments
to improve image detail. In my career as an art conservator, we often manipulate images to bring
out faint signatures, underdrawings of paintings, etc that are originally of low contrast.
Also, make sure your scanner is set at black and white, rather than a multi-color selection.

-Doug Sanders

__________________________________
Do you Yahoo!?
Yahoo! SiteBuilder - Free, easy-to-use web site design software
http://sitebuilder.yahoo.com

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Scanning
messages.msgSnippet: The term is spelled moire -with a French accent over the e. It refers to the concentric ring-like effect when certain patterns (in particular those of a linear
messages.messageBody:
The term is spelled moire -with a French accent over the e. It refers to the concentric ring-like
effect when certain patterns (in particular those of a linear nature) are displayed on a computer
monitor, for instance. Although I am by no means a desktop publishing expert, I would question
your need to scan at such a high resolution. What will be the final format upon which your
objects are shown? Website, print-out, computer screen? Many scanners have high settings, but
actually interpolate, or fill in the gaps, to create a false 'high resolution'. Perhaps you could
scan at 600 or so and capture enough information.
Also, I have found sometimes, that after you scan, you may see a moire pattern on the photoshop
window, but if you enlarge or reduce the image by a step, the pattern goes away. It's all about
trying to display a continuous image in a pixellated manner.
Regards,
Doug Sanders
--- Gordon Robson <robsongo@...> wrote:
> Hi all,
>
> I'm looking for a little free advice on scanning. I am using a
> Canoscan9900F, which is a very good scanner. I begin my scans through
> Photoshop 7.0 into ScanGear CS. I have been using very high dpis of
> 1600 and 800 with the weak morei (spelling?) turned on and the sharp
> turned off. I am still getting nasty looking morei in my scans of
> oshigata for this summer's lecture. Any ideas on what I need to do to
> improve my scans?
>
> Gordon
>
>
>


__________________________________

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Scanning
messages.msgSnippet: I don t know what morei is, I m afraid. My scanner has under a heading titled advanced a feature called Descreen which is essential for several types of
messages.messageBody:
I don't know what morei is, I'm afraid.

My scanner has under a heading titled advanced a feature called Descreen which is essential for several types of images.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: "temple carving" on tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Thanks, Afu. Apparently, in Japan it is referred to a Manji symbol, and used on maps to indicate the location of temples. I was told about a web-site which
messages.messageBody:
Thanks, Afu. Apparently, in Japan it is referred to a Manji symbol, and used on maps to indicate the location of temples.

I was told about a web-site which offered the following:

____ The omote ("front side," or since it is customarily on the left side, left) [clockwise moving] manji represents infinite mercy, or the love of Dharma which permeates the universe and nurtures all things. The ura ("back side," or right) manji represents intellect and strength. The Chinese are said to have derived their symbol for strength [symbol at very top of this page] from the ura manji. Although omote manji and ura manji are customarily used side by side in Buddhism, the manji worn on Shorinji Kenpo uniforms in Japan and many foreign countries, is set as the omote manji.
____ The spirit of caring for others as well as oneself is shown by the original teachings of Buddha. This path can be followed by using the intellect and strength symbolized by the ura manji to develop oneself into a person who can be relied on, and who can serve humankind as an expression of the mercy and love represented by the omote manji



____ The harmony of opposites symbolized in the manji includes the harmony of intellect with mercy, and strength with love. This harmony lies at the heart of Kongo Zen's principle or riki ai funi, a principle which also gives guidance to us in how we are meant to practice and to use the techniques of Shorinji Kenpo. Understanding the truths represented by the manji are vital to understanding the heart of Kongo Zen.

David





----- Original Message -----
From: Afu
To: token_kenkyu_kai@...
Sent: Tuesday, August 05, 2003 6:16 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: "temple carving" on tsuba


David,
There were a lot of small Buddhist Temples in Viet Nam with this symbol on top, in the same place you would see a cross on a Christian edifice.
Ganbatte!
Afu
afu@...
For books in English on Nihon Tô, go to:
http://www.afuresearch.com

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: "temple carving" on tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: I believe you pictured the tsuba upside down, so whatever is there needs to be looked at after the tsuba is rotated 180 degrees. It my be a Buddhist symbol
messages.messageBody:
I believe you pictured the tsuba upside down, so whatever is there needs to be looked at after the tsuba is rotated 180 degrees. It my be a Buddhist symbol that looks like a swastika or it may be something totally unrelated

Mark Jones
nixe@...


----- Original Message -----
From: David Zincavage
To: token_kenkyu_kai@...
Cc: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, August 05, 2003 3:31 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: "temple carving" on tsuba


But what are temple carvings? Are they symbols of good luck placed on the tsuba to protect its owner? Or are they ownership marks indicating that sword and/or tsuba are the property of a particular temple?

----- Original Message -----
From: RDavis@...
To: token_kenkyu_kai@...
Sent: Tuesday, August 05, 2003 11:27 AM
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: "temple carving" on tsuba


David....looks like the Buddhist symbol that is in the form of the German swastika only the "arms" are in the opposite direction. I have a tachi tsuba that has this same symbol in sukashi style just outside the seppa dai area.



Roger



-----Original Message-----
From: David Zincavage [mailto:jdz@...]
Sent: Tuesday, August 05, 2003 11:14 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Cc: token_kenkyu_kai@...
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: "temple carving" on tsuba



Whoops! I forgot to mention it is on the right side of the seppa dai.

----- Original Message -----


From: David Zincavage

To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com

Cc: token_kenkyu_kai@...

Sent: Tuesday, August 05, 2003 11:10 AM

Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: "temple carving" on tsuba



I have uploaded the image in a very large size in order to make the temple mark visible.

http://zincavage.org/AkasakaClouds.html
----- Original Message -----
From: alchemyst
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, August 05, 2003 9:05 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: "temple carving" on tsuba


--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "David Zincavage" <jdz@i...>
wrote:
> I just bought a tsuba which the dealer describes as having " a
small
temple
> carving symbol on the seppadai." I could not recognize it in the
pictures.
> What sort of temple carvings appear on tsubas?

On the seppa-dai ????

All sorts of "real" and abstract temples are used
as motifs on the body of the tsuba.

A picture would be most helpful.

Rich

messages.subject: Re: "temple carving" on tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: I just bought a tsuba which the dealer describes as having  a small temple carving symbol on the seppadai. I could not recognize it in the pictures. What
messages.messageBody:
I just bought a tsuba which the dealer describes as having " a small temple
carving symbol on the seppadai." I could not recognize it in the pictures.
What sort of temple carvings appear on tsubas?
